captions.text: What are you grinning at, you ghost?

- Oh, my God.
- What? What is it?

I only saw him years later
when he was worn down by life.

He's got his whole life in front of him,
and I'm not even a glint in his eye.
What do I say to him?

Why don't you introduce him
to his granddaughter?

I just wanted to thank you folks
for putting up this field...

This is my daughter Karin.
Karin, this is my...
Well, we're going to let you two talk.

If all these people are going to come,
we got a lot of work to do.
It was very nice meeting you.

title: Field of Dreams (8/9) Movie CLIP - Ray Meets His Father (1989) HD

comments.author: Josh Levy

comments.text:
It's the little things in life, a summer evening playing catch with your 
Dad. A simpler time for all of us. There's even a line in the movie: "We 
just don't recognize life's most significant moments while they're 
happening. Back then I thought, 'Well, there'll be other days.' I didn't 
realize that that was the only day." That line sticks with me. How many of 
us wouldn't give anything to go back and have one last catch with our Dads, 
and really appreciate it? Damn onions.﻿
comments.author: Chris _B

comments.text:
Who was Ray referring to when he said, "It was you."  Was he talking to his 
father or Shoeless Joe?  I always thought he was referring to his father, 
but Wikipedia says he was referring to Joe, which, I think, does not make 
sense.﻿
comments.author: KoachKrab127

comments.text:
When Ray said "It was you", he was under the impression that the whispers 
that he had heard on a few occasions earlier in the movie were from 
Shoeless Joe Jackson.

But when Shoeless Joe retorted "No Ray, it was you", Shoeless Joe was 
telling Ray that the whispers he had been hearing were of his own voice.

See, there was a point in the movie where Ray and Terry were trampsing 
about the countryside late one night in Ray's VW van talking about how Ray 
walked out on his father when he was only 14 or so because Ray stated that 
he could never respect a man whose hero was a criminal.

He was referring to how his father John (the guy in the catchers equipment 
above) had idolized Shoeless Joe when John was a younger man.

The whispers that Ray had been hearing earlier in the movie were of his own 
voice because he had grown up hating his father because Ray thought his dad 
idolized a criminal.

comments.author: ExMormon66

comments.text:
They both knew, if you look at his dad when meeting his family for the 
first time he is very humbled and forlorn. When Ray almost says who he is 
John looks like he is hanging on every word to be called "father" or "dad". 

The unspokeness of what is going on makes that scene what it is...Men 
raised in John's era didn't voice things, they kept it all inside. I know 
that because I was raised by a man like John Kinsela and honestly I 
couldn't imagine a better childhood..

Would love another catch with my dad....Every man who's seen this movie and 
lost their father either breaks down during the scene or has to fight it 
hard..

comments.author: ExMormon66

comments.text:
+r5t6y12,

That also explains why Annie's brother Mark (Timothy Busfield) didn't see 
the players on the field at anytime before Karin starts choking on the hot 
dog and Doc Graham travels through time crossing the base line between home 
plate and first base.

At some point before Karin starts choking on the hot dog everybody saw the 
players on the field except for Mark. As soon as Doc Graham crosses over 
the baseline the "space time continuum" is altered forever (except for this 
scene above). John was never brought out of the 1930s. At various points 
during the movie everybody else at the baseball field was.

That also explains why Terrence Mann saw the same "Moonlight Graham" 
message on the scoreboard at the professional baseball game but he didn't 
say anything about it to Ray until Ray was turning around in the street 
after dropping Terrence Mann off at home after the game.

It was all part of the plan. Except for Mark (Annie's brother) and John 
(Ray's father).
comments.author: r5t6y12

comments.text:
No, he didn't.

John is living in 1939. Ray is living in 1989. Even though they're standing 
2 feet away from each other there's a 50 year window between them that's 
invisible.

comments.text: "No Ray, it was you.' the best line in the film.﻿
comments.author: smarthearts71

comments.text:
+r5t6y12 In the scene Ray says 'ease HIS pain' thinking it was to ease his 
father's pain at not following his dream of playing baseball. But in 
reality he built the base ball field to reconcile HIS (Ray's) own pain and 
guilt for not loving baseball when his father was alive and thus 
rejecting his father. Baseball and his love/hate relationship he had with 
his father are the common link.
comments.author: smarthearts71

comments.text:
..........and it's not even the line itself as much as the volume at which 
it is spoken.

It's not possible that any regular person would have heard Ray say "it was 
you" from the middle of center field while he was standing by first base. 
It wouldn't be possible for Ray to hear someone say "No Ray, it was you" 
under the same condition in return.
comments.author: r5t6y12

comments.author: Smith Smithson

comments.text:
There are what I call "moments" in film. Where a scene, especially speaks 
to the  heart, soul, and deep emotions within all of us. This is one of 
those "moments". This film has several of these "moments". This film is one 
continuous "moment". ﻿
comments.author: Robert Milton

comments.text:
No other movie has ever made me tear up like this scene. At first I thought 
it was just me, but I see I have plenty of company. 

 When he first sees his dad there is something spiritual and eternal and 
poignant that transcends your life time to take you back to the earliest 
memories you have of playing catch with your dad.  Of him still being young 
and no gray hair and not worn down by life. How we can appreciate dad now 
in a way that was impossible to us as small kids.

This scene touches a memory and finds a place deep in your soul that   
connects you to your dad that transcends time and death and brings you 
together again.

I hope we all make it to heaven and we can play catch with our dads again. 
That thought alone holds promise and hope and anticipation of what waits on 
the other side. Have your glove ready dad.﻿

comments.text: Well said .Lost my dad in 1983 ,and still miss him terribly

comments.author: walter duvall

comments.text:
My father tore his ACL. The doctor said he doubts he would ever play again. 
It's moments like this in the movie make me appreciate all those times I 
was able to play soccer with him. All those drives to the park, him being 
there to comfort me after a loss. telling me how well we played. I wish I 
can go back in time for one night while he was in his prime to play a 
evening of soccer. I cry watching this every time.﻿

What a ridiculous comment that you have made, and have made on multiple 
clips of this movie.  If you count his wife standing up against banning a 
book as "liberal activism", then you have no concept of what activism truly

school and her "Brownie" meetings.  She did nothing that detracted from 
this ending or the movie in general.

comments.author: Ants250

comments.text:
Boy, does this make me think of my dad as well. He and I both love sports. 
We love to talk about it and toss our predictions & musings back and forth. 
We love to play them too. Except he's past 50 now and since he has bad back 
problems, it's hard for him to just play catch. This clip really opened my 
mind to his true feelings- his eyes may be tired but they still shine with 
youth and energy. It hurts him to throw a baseball or football now, but he 
still does it and loves it- because playing ball with his son seems like a 
dream he always had. I have two sisters but no brothers, so my dad and I 
have always been very close. ﻿

comments.text:
Maybe I can't really understand, because I'm a girl...but just like a boy 
has a bond with his dad that I'll never understand, a little girl has a 
bond with her daddy that no one else will be able to understand, either. 
I've gotten to have my whole life with my dad, and I'm very blessed to have 
him. I'm sorry for your loss, and I'll pray for you. 'Is this heaven?' 
'It's Iowa.' 'Iowa? I could have sworn this was heaven.' 'Is there a 
heaven?' 'Oh yeah. It's the place where dreams come true.'

comments.text:
Well this movie came out in 1988 I believe, and even in the movie Kevin 
Costner bemoans how "the game" isn't what it used to be. So I'm not sure if 
there ever really was a pure time for baseball, this movie plays with the 
fantasy and myth of the wholesome All-American quality of baseball. I don't 
think anything like that ever existed. But it's nice to pretend like it 
once did.

comments.author: bizarrosean

comments.text:
I saw this film when I was 19, my dad and me got along perfectly, he was in 
perfect health, and I was blown away by the movie. Changed the way I looked 
at movies and life. saw it 19 times afterwards in the theatre. Now my dad 
has recently had a stroke and heart attack, beginning stages of dementia 
and when I revisit this film....the scenes I once loved and had floored me 
- mean entirely something else to me now. They are so close to the bone, it 
is unreal. The pain now when watching this scene.
comments.author: fabooshness
